Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open and notes scattered around me, outlining the session I’d promised to run for my mentees. The project deadline was looming, and I knew they were counting on me to help them grasp the final concepts. Just as I was mapping out the last activity, my younger brother plopped down beside me, eyes bright. “We’re talking about what to do this weekend—come help us decide!” My mom called from the living room, “We want everyone’s input!” I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure of time. My family expected me to be present, to laugh and plan with them, but my mentees needed me to be prepared, to guide them through the skills they were struggling with. My mind raced, torn between the warmth of family togetherness and the responsibility I felt toward my mentees. I could hear their voices in my head, both groups waiting, both expecting me to show up fully. My hands hovered over my keyboard, heart pounding, as I tried to figure out how to be both the sibling my family wanted and the mentor my students needed.
